snippet: As Hong Kong braces for demonstrations over voting rights, its relations with mainland China have been overshadowed by a more pedestrian issue: how to react when toddlers relieve themselves on the street.
abstract: Hong Kong braces for demonstrations over voting rights, but its relations with mainland China have been overshadowed by a more pedestrian issue: how to react when toddlers relieve themselves on the street; video-recorded tussle when mainland couple allowed their child to urinate on street has ignited social media uproar; argument about child's behavior comes as local attitudes toward Beijing appear to be hardening.
lead_paragraph: As Hong Kong braces for demonstrations over voting rights, its relations with mainland China have been overshadowed by a more pedestrian issue: how to react when toddlers relieve themselves on the street.

headline.main: Call of Nature Becomes a Call to Arms in Hong Kong
